awd_titl_txt: Contact Angle Hysteresis on Curved Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Contact between liquid droplets and solids arise in many everyday settings such as rain droplets on a car, condensation of dew on plant leaves, or insects walking on water ponds. To understand or control the behavior of these and related systems, we must first understand the shape of the fluid surfaces and the forces that they can apply. In all of these systems, there is an interface between two fluids (air and water, for example), which meets the surface of a solid object. The angle between the fluid interface and the solid surface (the "contact angle") is the key parameter that determines the interface shape and the forces applied by the fluids. Experiments show that the contact angle has a consistent value when a fluid interface advances across a dry surface, and a smaller value when the interface recedes (moves in the other direction). This variability of the contact angle, known as hysteresis, determines key properties such as whether droplets slide off a surface or remain trapped. There is no general theory for contact-angle hysteresis, but it is typically thought to be an inherent property of the materials being used. This project investigates a new finding that contact angle hysteresis also varies with the shape of the fluid interface. The project is important because understanding the role of geometry in contact-angle hysteresis will give broader insights into the phenomenon that we currently lack. Ultimately, the results of this project will contribute to improved technological processes such as coating of fibers with fluids, stabilizing oil droplets with particles in food or oil-recovery applications, and even assembling electronic components by floating them on a liquid surface.

This project will provide measurements of the of the contact-line shape and the contact angle by direct observation under conditions of advancing and receding fluids. Chemical treatment of the solid surface will be varied and a range of fluids will be used. Experiments focus on millimeter-scale objects so that the interface can be directly visualized. From the known interface shapes, the surface energies will be calculated numerically and, where possible, analytically. These results will allow testing of proposed mechanisms of contact-angle hysteresis. In addition to generating new basic science, the proposed research will support educational projects for local middle-school students and career training for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project provided new fundamental understanding of the behavior of fluid interfaces in contact with solid surfaces. Contacts between fluid interfaces and solid surfaces arise in diverse settings ranging from water droplets condensing on a surface to particles coating oil droplets in water. Our major research goal is to identify mechanisms that determine the angle between a fluid interface and a solid surface, known as the contact angle. (See the attached figure for a definition.) The contact angle plays the key role in determining the shapes of droplets on surfaces, or the position of particles that bind at a liquid interface. The angle is therefore critical to applications such as water-repellant surfaces or Pickering emulsions in the food or oil-recovery industries.

Although the equilibrium value of the contact angle can be predicted, more than a century of experiments shows that the measured contact angle is not generally in equilibrium. Instead, the measured value depends on the history of the system, a phenomenon called hysteresis. Contact-angle hysteresis occurs even on smooth, clean surfaces. In prior studies of contact-angle hysteresis, proposed mechanisms depend on properties that are intrinsic to the materials. Here we investigated recent findings that contact-angle hysteresis is not entirely a product of material properties. Even with smooth surfaces, the shape of the solid surface and of the contact line also affect hysteresis.

Intellectual merit - This project consisted of experiments and numerical calculations to study contact-angle hysteresis at interfaces having a variety of shapes and surface chemistry to obtain an understanding of the mechanism. From that overarching goal, research progressed along five projects that address aspects of contact angle hysteresis, the role of geometry, and the role of electrostatic charge at the interface. The studies that we carried out as part of this project are: (1) measuring advancing and receding contact angles on curved solid surfaces, (2) measuring the dynamics of contact-line motion on heterogeneous surfaces to see how large an area is affected when a segment of the contact line moves, (3) measurements of the net charge left on a surface after a liquid droplet slides past, and (4) studying how interfacial charge affects forces between solid surfaces and fluid interfaces. Our fifth study focused on curvature anisotropy in a different kind of fluid interface: (5) lipid bilayer membranes associating with curved solid particles.  These experiments were carried out by graduate and undergraduate students working together with the PI.

To summarize one key finding of this project: We investigated a useful model system of water droplets hanging from or sliding along borosilicate glass with a clean adsorbed layer of silicone (PDMS). In one set of experiments, we varied the shape of the glass surface. We found that when the solid cylinder is viewed from the side, the receding angle (the contact angle of the droplet as it slowly shrinks by evaporation) was significantly higher on rods with a higher curvature (smaller radius). Whereas a flat surface had a receding angle of 85 degrees, we found that the angle rose to 95 degrees on a highly curved cylinder. (see attached image.) We propose that the control parameter that quantifies the effect of curvature may be the ratio of the droplet diameter and the solid-cylinder radius. In our experiments, the advancing angle (formed when the droplet was slowly expanding by addition of water) was always 103 degrees, independent of surface shape. The change of shape of the contact line with advancing or receding may hold the key to the origin of the geometry dependence. For example, expanding a drop in the shape of a spherical cap involves displacing a circular contact line, whereas a more complex shape requires displacement of a longer, undulating contact line shaped like the rim of a saddle. By tuning geometry and seeing how this competition works, we seek a better conceptual model for hysteresis and a way to quantify the dissipative energy terms that must be present.  

Broader Impact - The project supported the training of 10 undergraduate and graduate students for careers in science or engineering, and it supported outreach to K-12 students and teachers. The project also supported training for more than 200 graduate students in the general area of the research program, through the UMass Summer School on Complex Fluids and Soft Solids. The broader impacts of this project include dissemination of our science and materials to industry.

This project is part of a broader effort to develop new science and engineering principles to address our nation's technological needs and physical infrastructure. Quantitative and predictive insight into the origin of contact-angle hysteresis is a valuable contribution to science and engineering related to fluid interfaces. We anticipate that our results will guide future development of wetting-based materials for icephobic, self-drying, self-cleaning or water-harvesting applications and for particle-stabilized emulsions in foods or coatings.


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Anthony D Dinsmore

    Anthony Dinsmore and Nesrin Senbil
    Public Domain
    Anthony D Dinsmore
    Contact angles
  • Data showing how the contact angle changes with substrate shape. The upper part shows the geometry and the lower part shows the results of measurements. The advancing angle was constant but the receding angle rose significantly with substrate curvature.
    Anthony Dinsmore and Mingzhu Cui
    Public Domain
    Anthony D Dinsmore
    Contact-angle-and-curvature
